stem: You are caring for a 62-year-old male patient, Mr. Johnson, who has a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) and an intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring device in situ. Review the provided patient information and select all of the nursing interventions that are appropriate for this patient.

options.text: Maintain the head of the bed (HOB) at 30-45 degrees.
options.rationale: Elevating the HOB promotes venous drainage from the brain, which helps to reduce ICP. This is important for patients with ICP monitoring devices. Furthermore, the LVAD benefits from decreased preload, achieved via gravity-assisted venous return reduction.

options.text: Routinely flush the LVAD driveline with sterile saline.
options.rationale: Flushing the LVAD driveline is not a routine nursing intervention and could introduce infection or damage the device. LVAD drivelines have specific care protocols that do not include routine flushing. Instead, meticulous assessment for signs of infection and adherence to sterile technique during dressing changes are paramount.

options.text: Logroll the patient every 2 hours to prevent pressure ulcers.
options.rationale: Logrolling helps to maintain spinal alignment and prevent pressure ulcers in immobile patients. Given the presence of both an LVAD and an ICP monitor, meticulous skin care and pressure ulcer prevention strategies are essential.

options.text: Administer prescribed stool softeners to prevent straining during bowel movements.
options.rationale: Straining during bowel movements (Valsalva maneuver) can increase ICP. Stool softeners can help prevent constipation and reduce the risk of straining. Additionally, increased intra-abdominal pressure from straining could negatively impact LVAD function.

options.text: Assess neurological status using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) every 4 hours.
options.rationale: Regular neurological assessments using the GCS are crucial to monitor for changes in the patient's level of consciousness and to detect any signs of increased ICP. Early detection allows for timely intervention.

options.text: Monitor LVAD parameters and alarms per hospital protocol.
options.rationale: Continuous monitoring of LVAD parameters is essential to ensure proper device function and to detect any potential complications, such as pump thrombosis or outflow obstruction. Adhering to hospital protocols ensures standardized and safe LVAD management.

options.text: Encourage deep coughing and incentive spirometry every 2 hours.
options.rationale: While pulmonary hygiene is important, forceful coughing can transiently increase ICP. Gentle coughing exercises and alternative methods of secretion clearance should be considered. Incentive spirometry is acceptable if tolerated without a significant increase in ICP.

SBAR.situation: Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old male with an LVAD and ICP monitor, admitted for altered mental status. He has a history of heart failure and recent fall.
SBAR.background: Patient underwent LVAD implantation 6 months ago. ICP monitor was placed 2 days ago following a witnessed unwitnessed fall at home. Baseline ICP has been between 8-12 mmHg. He is on continuous heparin infusion per protocol.
SBAR.assessment: At 0800, patient is somnolent but arousable to voice. GCS is 13 (Eyes 3, Verbal 4, Motor 6). ICP is currently 18 mmHg. LVAD parameters are within normal limits. Neurological exam shows no new focal deficits. Vitals: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 70 bpm (LVAD-supported), RR 16, SpO2 96% on 2L NC, Temp 37.2Â°C. Small abrasion noted on the forehead. Pupils are equal and reactive.
SBAR.recommendation: I recommend notifying the neurosurgeon regarding the elevated ICP. Consider ordering a CT scan of the head to rule out new hemorrhage. Evaluate the need for mannitol or hypertonic saline to reduce ICP. Continue close neurological monitoring and LVAD parameter assessment. Strict I/O monitoring is essential. Implement seizure precautions.

clinicalPearls: Patients with LVADs often have a non-palpable pulse and a MAP (Mean Arterial Pressure) should be used for blood pressure assessment.
Avoid aggressive coughing or Valsalva maneuvers in patients with elevated ICP.
Meticulous skin care is crucial to prevent infection in patients with LVAD drivelines and ICP monitoring devices.
questionTrap: Selecting interventions that are generally good nursing care but are contraindicated by either the LVAD or the ICP monitoring.
mnemonic: HEADS UP: HOB elevation, Evaluate neuro status, Avoid straining, Driveline care, Stool softeners, Understand LVAD Parameters, Prevent pressure ulcers.
references: Neurocritical Care Society Guidelines for ICP Monitoring
